solution_line_template: Sam worked for {sam_hours} hours yesterday, so he was able to complete {sam_hours} hours * {minutes_per_hour} minutes per hour / {sam_minutes_per_widget} minutes per widget = <<{sam_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}/{sam_minutes_per_widget}={sam_widgets}>>{sam_widgets} widgets.

Jack worked for {jack_hours} hours, so he was able to complete {jack_hours} hours * {minutes_per_hour} minutes per hour / {jack_minutes_per_widget} minutes per widget = <<{jack_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}/{jack_minutes_per_widget}={jack_widgets}>>{jack_widgets} widgets.

Sam, Jack, and Tony were able to complete {total_widgets} widgets together. So of those, Tony personally completed {total_widgets} widgets - {sam_widgets} widgets - {jack_widgets} widgets = <<{total_widgets}-{sam_widgets}-{jack_widgets}={tony_widgets}>>{tony_widgets} widgets.

It took Tony {tony_hours} hours to complete those {tony_widgets} widgets, so he takes {tony_hours} hours * {minutes_per_hour} minutes per hour / {tony_widgets} widgets = <<{tony_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}/{tony_widgets}={tony_minutes_per_widget}>>{tony_minutes_per_widget} minutes per widget.
